journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Balanced calibration of resonant shunt circuits for piezoelectric vibration control

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Technical University of Denmark, Kongens Lyngby, Denmark

author-notes.corresp: Jan Høgsberg, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Technical University of Denmark, Nils Koppels Alle, Building 403, DK-2800 Kongens Lyngby, Denmark. Email: jhg@mek.dtu.dk

abstract.p: Shunting of piezoelectric transducers and suitable electric circuits constitutes an effective passive approach to resonant vibration damping of structures. Most common design concepts for resonant resistor-inductor (RL) shunt circuits rely on either maximization of the attainable modal damping or minimization of the frequency response amplitude. However, the former is suboptimal near resonance due to constructive interference of the two modes with identical frequency, and the latter results in reduced implemented damping. This article proposes an explicit pole placement–based design procedure for both series and parallel RL circuits. The procedure relies on equal modal damping and sufficient separation of the complex poles to avoid constructive interference of the two modes. By comparison with existing design procedures, it is demonstrated that the present calibration leads to a balanced compromise between large modal damping and effective response reduction with limited damping effort.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The piezoelectric effect can be used to convert some of the vibration energy in a structure to electric energy, and by shunting with an electric circuit, some of the energy may be dissipated in the resistance
R
. The efficiency of the various types of piezoelectric damping strategies depends very much on the coupling between the piezoelectric and the structure (Preumont et al., 2008). Advances in piezoelectric material research have lead to an increase in the electromechanical coupling, whereby effective passive vibration damping by shunted piezoelectric transducers has become feasible. An overview of shunted piezoelectric vibration damping and control can be found in the books by Preumont (2006) and Moheimani and Fleming (2006) or the review article by Moheimani (2003).

Compared to the purely dissipative
R
circuit improved resonant damping can be obtained by the shunting with resistor–inductor (RL) circuits (Preumont et al., 2008), where the inductance
L
governs the natural frequency of the electric filter, while the resistance
R
introduces the damping representing the bandwidth of the filter. When the structure is vibrating and the piezoelectric transducer converts structural oscillations at the transducer location to oscillations in the applied voltage (or current), the effective damping and energy dissipation depend very much on proper calibration of the associated electric circuit. In practice, the fairly low capacitance of piezoelectric materials and the low frequencies associated with structural dynamics often lead to a relatively large inductance in the electric circuit, which therefore must be created synthetically (Belloli et al., 2007; Flemming et al., 2000).

The calibration of resonant shunt circuits for piezoelectric vibration damping is typically derived either from minimizing the frequency response amplitude or by maximizing the modal damping in a root locus or pole placement context. In Hagood and Von Flotow (1991), these calibration principles are used to derive the optimal system parameters for the series
RL
circuit. The response amplitude is minimized by choosing the system parameters, so that the dynamic amplification is the same at the two invariant fixed-point frequencies and the frequency of the electric circuit. Maximum modal damping is on the other hand obtained at the bifurcation point in the root locus diagram, and it corresponds to having double roots in the characteristic equation. The parallel
RL
circuit has been treated subsequently by Wu (1996) and a comparative study of the series and parallel
RL
circuits is presented in Park and Inman (1999). A detailed review of minimum (frequency response) amplitude calibration and the maximum damping (or double root) calibration for both series and parallel
RL
circuits is provided by Caruso (2001). The calibration and design of the classic resonant
RL
shunt circuits is still an active research topic, and recently Yamada et al. (2010) and Kozlowski et al. (2011) have applied the fixed-point approach by Den Hartog (1956) for the tuning of the
RL
circuit parameters. As already demonstrated in Hagood and Von Flotow (1991), calibration by maximum damping in the root locus diagram leads to an undesirable overshoot in the frequency response, while on the other hand, a minimum frequency response calibration typically results in a reduction of the attained damping. Thus, the two common calibration approaches are — at least to some extent—conflicting, and this article proposes a simple and robust design strategy, which combines large and equal modal damping, effective response reduction, and limited control effort.

The design procedure is inspired by the analysis in Krenk (2005) for the mechanical tuned mass damper. In the classic design procedure by Den Hartog (1956), the spring stiffness of the tuned mass damper is initially chosen, so that the dynamic amplification of the structure is the same at the two fixed points, where the magnitude of the response is independent of the damper parameter. These fixed-point frequencies are similar to those used by Hagood and Von Flotow (1991) in the minimum amplitude calibration mentioned above. Following Brock (1946), the damping parameter is then determined as the mean value of the two damping parameters that provide a local maximum in the response amplitude at either of the two fixed-point frequencies. As demonstrated in Krenk (2005), this frequency tuning, combined with a slightly larger damping parameter, results in (a) equal modal damping, (b) a flat plateau in the frequency response amplitude, and (c) a flat plateau in the amplitude of the relative motion of the tuned mass. In fact, the somewhat larger damping parameter suggested in Krenk (2005) implies that the two complex poles follow
±
45
∘
paths for increasing mass ratio. By this deliberate separation of the poles in the complex plane, the effect of constructive interference of the two coupled vibration modes is minimized and the undesirable peak in the dynamic amplification is avoided. Furthermore, the optimal tuning of the tuned mass damper parameters can be conducted entirely by conditions associated with the complex poles corresponding to the roots of the characteristic polynomial. For other resonant formats, including those of the
RL
circuits, the fixed-point calibration procedure in terms of frequency response will not lead to equal modal damping, and in this article, the calibration is therefore based directly on the characteristic polynomial. A general description of this design procedure is given in Krenk and Høgsberg (2012), while the aim of this article is to apply this strategy specifically to resonant
RL
shunt circuits.

sec.title: Electromechanical system
sec.p:
The basic
RL
shunt circuits for resonant vibration control of structures are illustrated in Figure 1 by a laminate-type piezoelectric element attached to a cantilever beam. As indicated in Figure 1, the voltage over the electrodes of the piezoelectric is
V
. Because the natural frequencies of the structure are typically one or two orders of magnitude lower than the inherent natural frequency of the piezoelectric, the piezoelectric element may be considered as a capacitor with constant stress capacitance
C
p
in parallel with a current source
I
proportional to the strain rate of the piezoelectric. The resonance in the circuit is created by the inductance
L
in combination with the capacitance
C
p
, while the bandwidth or damping of the electric filter is provided by the resistance
R
. In Figure 1(a), the electric components
R
and
L
are placed in series, while in Figure 1(b), they are placed in parallel.

caption.p: (a) Series and (b) parallel resonant shunt circuits.

sec.p: In this section, the equations of motion for the electromechanical system are presented first, and a single-mode representation then yields an equivalent set of scalar equations used for the calibration of the resonant circuits in the section “Equal damping calibration.”

sec.title: Equations of motion
sec.p:
In the numerical analysis of structures, the equations of motion are typically obtained by discretization in terms of, e.g. finite elements. Assuming harmonic motion represented via the complex exponential factor
e
i ω t

ω

The vector
x

M

D
is the structural damping matrix, and
K
s

f

V
over the electrodes, the piezoelectric coupling coefficient
θ
p

w

where

where

Q
in the electric system

The constant strain capacitance

of the piezoelectric is given in terms of the associated constant stress capacitance

where the quasi-static coupling coefficient

This expression represents the ratio between apparent electric stiffness

sec.p:

u
and modal coordinate
x

The vibration form
u

sec.title: Resonant shunt circuits
sec.p:
The electric shunt circuits in Figure 1 are calibrated to provide a desired resonant reaction to the vibrating mechanical system. The electric circuits are conveniently defined in terms of the impedance
Z
, which represents the relation between the voltage
V
and the current
I = i ω Q

The voltage
V
in equation (10) is eliminated by this relation, and the frequency domain equations (12) and (10) can then be written as

In the following, the impedance formats for the individual
RL
circuits are substituted into equation (16).

sec.p:
For the circuit in Figure 1(a), where the resistance
R
and the inductance
L

By substitution into equation (16), the equations (15) and (16) can be written in the following normalized form

e

By elimination of

where the denominator represents the characteristic polynomial governing the complex natural frequencies of the system. The control effort is represented by the applied voltage

Elimination of

and

where the constant term in the numerator has been canceled by the term on the right-hand side of equation (19).

Using equation (23), the expression for the normalized amplitude of the applied voltage is

sec.title: Equal damping calibration
sec.p:
For resonant damping formats, the characteristic polynomial is of order four, with complex-valued frequencies
ω
1
, … ,
ω
4
as roots. In the following, it is assumed that
ω
1
and
ω
2
are located in the quadrant with positive real part, while
ω
3
and
ω
4
appear symmetrically in the quadrant with negative real part. The basis of the present calibration is equal modal damping. As demonstrated in Krenk (2005), for the mechanical tuned mass damper, this property requires that
ω
1
and
ω
2
are located on the same line, which also contains the origin of the complex plane, as indicated by the circle markers in Figure 2. Thus, equal modal damping requires that
ω
1
and
ω
2
are inverse points with respect to a real-valued reference frequency
ω
0
via the relation
ω
2
/
ω
0
=
ω
0
/
ω
¯
1
, where the bar represents the complex conjugate. Graphically, this inverse relation implies that the complex roots are located symmetrically with respect to a circle centered at the origin of the complex plane with radius
ω
0
, shown in Figure 2 by a thin solid line. The inverse relation is satisfied by a quadratic polynomial of the form (Krenk and Høgsberg, 2012)

with nondimensional parameters
λ
and
χ
. Multiplica-tion by
ω
2
ω
0
2
gives the characteristic polynomial

sec.p:
The root locus diagram for
ω
1
and
ω
2
is shown in Figure 2 for
χ = 0 . 5
and with
λ
as gain parameter. For
λ = 0
, the two frequencies are real-valued. For increasing
λ
, the frequencies move into the complex plane, and for
λ ≤ 1
, two connected frequencies are located on the same line representing equal modal damping. For
λ = 1
, the frequencies
ω
1
and
ω
2
meet at the bifurcation point
ω
b
, indicated by the cross in Figure 2. This particular point corresponds to double roots in the characteristic polynomial (33). For
λ > 1
, the two frequencies branch off and follow the circle with radius
ω
0
. One of the roots approaches the imaginary axis, whereby the associated mode becomes critically damped, whereas the other root approaches the real-axis, whereby this mode becomes undamped. Thus, maximum modal damping is obtained at the bifurcation point
ω
1
=
ω
2
=
ω
b
, and calibration based on double roots in the characteristic polynomial might seem attractive. However, as demonstrated in Krenk (2005) and Krenk and Høgsberg (2012), identical (double) roots lead to constructive interference of the two modes. This means that a balance between large modal damping and effective response mitigation requires a suitable separation of the complex roots in the root locus diagram. For the mechanical tuned mass damper in Krenk (2005), this compromise is obtained for
λ =
1
2
2
, which corresponds to the circle markers in Figure 2. It subsequently follows from the equal modal damping property that for small damping levels, the actual modal damping ratio
ζ
can be estimated by the parameter
ζ
*
= λ χ =
1
2
2
χ
. Elimination of
χ
and
λ
in equation (33) provides the desired characteristic polynomial

which in the following will be used for calibration of the
RL
shunt circuit parameters. In the root locus diagram in Figure 3(a), the circular markers represent the trajectories of the complex roots of equation (34) for increasing
ζ
*
. The linear (solid) curves indicate that these trajectories move into the complex plane in
±
45
∘
directions. As demonstrated in Krenk (2005), this purely root locus–based property secures optimal frequency response characteristics for the mechanical tuned mass damper. Furthermore, it has been demonstrated in Krenk and Høgsberg (2012) that it leads to near optimal frequency characteristics for several other resonant control formats. The equal modal damping property is illustrated in Figure 3(b), where the modal damping ratio
ζ = Im [ ω ] / | ω |
of the two modes is plotted as a function of the desired damping ratio
ζ
*
. It is seen that the damping in the two modes is identical and that
ζ ≃
ζ ∗
within a level of damping that is sufficient for most dynamic problems.

caption.p:
(a) Root locus diagram and (b) modal damping ratio,
ζ
*
= 0 , 0 . 01 , 0 . 02 , … , 0 . 2
; optimal frequency separation
( ° )
; and double root
( × )
.

sec.p:
Alternatively, calibration can be based on the condition of double roots of the characteristic equation, which corresponds to
λ = 1
in equation (33) and the bifurcation point in Figure 2. As demonstrated by Hagood and Von Flotow (1991) and Caruso (2001), this leads to equal and large modal damping, and it is in the following referred to as maximum damping calibration. This calibration is represented in Figure 3 by the cross markers, and the trajectory follows the circle with radius
ω
0
in Figure 2.

In the following calibration analysis, the structural damping is omitted, i.e.
ζ
s
= 0
. However, as shown in Krenk and Høgsberg (2012), structural damping and the damping introduced by the resonant control are approximately additive in the case of harmonic response, and
ζ
*
therefore represents the required supplemental damping.

sec.title: Series RL circuit
sec.p:
The present design of the series
RL
circuit follows directly from comparison of the denominator in equation (22) and the generic equation (34). First, the reference frequency
ω
0
is determined by comparison of the constant terms. Subsequently, the filter frequency
ω
e
is obtained by comparison of the ratio between the linear and cubic terms. This leads to
The damping parameters are then determined by comparison of the quadratic terms and the coefficients to the cubic terms. The results can be written as

where the approximation is valid for
κ
2
<< 1
. The latter expression shows that the attainable damping ratio
ζ
*
is about half the damping ratio of the electric circuit
ζ
e
. Substitution of the expressions (21) for
ω
e
and
ζ
e
provides the corresponding calibration formulae for the circuit components

When comparing these expressions with the maximum damping calibration in Caruso (2001), the inductance
L
is identical, while the resistance
R
is a factor
2
smaller. This is because the present design relies on the
±
45
∘
separation of the roots in the complex plane.

The design expressions for the series
RL
circuit are summarized in Table 1. This table is organized as a design procedure. Based on the required additional damping
ζ
*
, the corresponding desired electromechanical coupling parameter
κ
2
is given by the first expression in Table 1. Once
κ
2
has been estimated for the actual system (Delperro et al., 2011; Porfiri et al., 2007), the associated electric circuit components
L
and
R
are chosen according to the expressions in the bottom rows of Table 1.

Figure 4(a) shows the frequency response amplitude
x
given by equation (22), while Figure 4(b) shows the corresponding frequency amplitude of the applied voltage
V
from equation (24). The solid curve represents the present calibration of the series
RL
circuit presented in equations (35) and (36). The dashed curves represent the maximum damping calibration (Caruso, 2001; Hagood and Von Flotow, 1991). As seen in Figure 4(a), the maximum damping calibration leads to an undesirable peak in the dynamic amplification, which indicates that this procedure is not optimal for damping of structures dominated by resonant response. The dotted curves in Figure 4 represent the calibration based on the minimization of the frequency response amplitude (Caruso, 2001), while the dashed-dotted curves represent the fixed-point calibration proposed in Yamada et al. (2010). Both methods rely on optimization of the frequency response curves, and as seen in Figure 4(a), they provide the desired flat plateau around resonance. However, as seen in Figure 4(b), these methods introduce an overshoot in the frequency amplitude of the applied voltage. Thus, the present calibration method seems to represent a balanced compromise between effective frequency amplitude attenuation and limited control effort. The system parameters for the frequency response curves are summarized in Table 2, where the third and fourth rows are for the present series
RL
shunt circuit, while the fifth and sixth rows represent the parallel circuit treated in the section “Parallel RL circuit.”

sec.p:
The root locus diagram is presented in Figure 4(c) for
ζ
*
= 0 … 0 . 2
. The maximum damping calibration (dashed curve) leads to a single trajectory, while the two trajectories of the present balanced calibration (solid curves) initially follow the desired
±
45
∘
directions. Figure 4(d) shows the corresponding damping ratio, and it is seen that both calibration concepts secure equal modal damping. Because of the different frequency tuning, this desirable property is lost for the minimum amplitude calibration (dotted curves) and the fixed-point calibration (dashed-dotted curves). Both strategies lead to a reduction in the apparent damping ratio of the targeted vibration mode, and thereby a reduced energy dissipation. This might result in a decreased damping performance with respect to, e.g. transient or stochastic loading conditions. The specific formulae for the maximum damping calibration (dashed curves), the minimum amplitude calibration (dotted curves), the fixed-point calibration (dashed-dotted curves), and the present balanced calibration (solid curves) are summarized in Appendix 1.

sec.title: Parallel RL circuit
sec.p:
As for the series circuit, the calibration of the parallel
RL
circuit is obtained by comparison of the denominator in equation (30) with the generic equation (34). For the frequency calibration, this leads to
while the damping ratios are determined as
By substitution of equation (29), the corresponding optimal circuit parameters are

Again the optimal inductance
L
is identical to that from the maximum damping calibration (Caruso, 2001). However, because
ζ
e
in equation (29) is inversely proportional to
R
, the present calibration gives a resistance that is a factor
2
larger compared to the double root calibration.

The calibration formulae for the electric parameters of the parallel circuit are summarized in the third column of Table 1, while the frequency response curves, the root locus diagram, and the damping ratios are shown in Figure 5. The frequency amplitudes for the response
x
and the voltage
V
are given in equations (30) and (31), respectively, and it follows from Figure 5(a) and (b) that the present design (solid curves) leads to a flat plateau in the frequency response curve without overshoot in the frequency amplitude of the applied voltage. Moreover, it is almost identical to the minimum amplitude calibration represented by the dotted curves. Figure 5(c) and (d) shows the root locus diagram and the corresponding damping ratio. As for the series circuit, it is seen that the present balanced calibration (solid curves) and the maximum damping calibration (dashed curves) both lead to equal modal damping, while this desirable property is not present for the two remaining amplitude-based calibration procedures. Thus, the conclusions are similar to those for the series circuit. The present design procedure leads to equal modal damping and provides a good balance between effective response reduction and limited magnitude of the control force.

in (c and d).

sec.title: Damping of beam structure
sec.p:
The balanced calibration procedure for
RL
shunt circuits is finally illustrated by the simple numerical example shown in Figure 6, where a laminate-type piezoelectric transducer acts on a cantilever beam. The length, width, and thickness of the beam are
ℓ = 250
mm
,
b = 50
mm
, and
t = 1 . 5
mm
, respectively, and the material is steel with elastic modulus
E = 210
GPa
and mass density
ρ = 7850
kg /
m
3

ℓ
p

b
p
= 32
mm
, and thickness
t
p
= 0 . 11
mm

, while the inertia of the laminate is neglected. The short-circuit stiffness of the piezoelectric is then approximated as

sec.p:
Consequently,
w
T
x
represents the change in cross-sectional rotation between the ends of the laminate. The natural frequency of the first mode of the beam with short-circuited transducer electrodes is
ω
s
= 127 . 4
rad / s
, corresponding to 20.3 Hz. The associated mode shape vector
u
is normalized to unit modal mass and the modal participation factor is
ν =

. This means that the nondimensional generalized electromechanical coupling coefficient in equation (13) is

2

The governing equations of motion for the beam with shunted piezoelectric transducer are obtained by combining equations (1), (4), and (14). By elimination of voltage
V
, they can be written as

where
ξ
p
= Q /
θ
p
is the normalized charge,
K
o

K
s
+ (
θ
p
2
/ C ) w
w
T
is the open-circuit stiffness matrix, and
Z
is the impedance of the electric circuit given in equation (17) for the series circuit and in equation (26) for the parallel circuit. The force vector
f
contains the transverse force
f
acting at the tip of the beam, see Figure 6(a). Figure 7(a) and (b) shows the frequency response amplitude of the beam tip displacement for the series and parallel
RL
shunt circuits, respectively. Since the amplitudes are normalized by the static deflection
x
tip
0
, the curves represent dynamic amplification. The four curves in Figure 7 represent the four calibration techniques summarized in Appendix 1 and presented previously in Figures 4 and 5 for the idealized single-mode representation. When applied to a flexible structure, the influence from residual vibration modes leads to a detuning of the system, which in the frequency response curves introduces a slight inclination of the plateau around resonance. This is also observed for the normalized applied voltage presented in Figure 7(c) and (d), which are obtained by via equation (4). The results for the flexible beam are otherwise quite similar to those for the idealized single-mode case with
ζ
*
= 0 . 02
in Figures 4 and 5.

sec.p:
The modal damping ratio can be determined as
ζ = Im [ ω ] / | ω |
, where the complex-valued natural frequency
ω
is found as the solution to the eigenvalue represented by equations (41) and (42) with
f = 0
. The modal damping ratios associated with the first vibration mode of the beam are presented in Table 3. It is seen that the balanced calibration recovers the estimated damping ratio
ζ
*
= 0 . 022
with quite good accuracy. Furthermore, it is observed that the equal modal damping property of the maximum damping calibration is lost and that the attainable modal damping for the minimum amplitude calibration and the fixed-point calibration is slightly reduced compared to the balanced calibration.

caption.p: Damping ratios for first vibration mode of cantilever beam.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
This article proposes a balanced calibration principle for the series and parallel
RL
shunt circuits often used in piezoelectric vibration damping. The principle is of the pole placement type and the explicit expressions for the parameters of the shunt circuits follow directly by comparison of the characteristic equation with a generic polynomial. This polynomial is constructed to ensure both large and equal modal damping and to secure a sufficient separation of the complex poles to avoid the constructive interference of closely spaced modes that results in an undesirable peak in the frequency response amplitude at resonance. The present design procedure is compared to existing design procedures from the literature in terms of a root locus and frequency response analysis. It is demonstrated that the present calibration strategy represents a balanced compromise between large attainable damping, effective frequency response reduction, and limited magnitude of the control. Thus, the calibration procedure proposed in this article could be a simple and robust candidate for the design of resonant piezoelectric vibration control of structures.

sec.title: Maximum damping calibration
sec.p: In Caruso (2001), the filter parameters are determined by maximizing the damping. For the series circuit, this leads to
while for the parallel circuit, it gives

Note that these expressions correspond to those obtained by design with respect to the double roots in the complex plane. In Figures 4 and 5, this maximum damping calibration is represented by the dashed curves.

sec.title: Minimum amplitude calibration
sec.p: As shown in Caruso (2001), minimization of the frequency response amplitudes leads to the following optimal parameters for the series circuit
while for the parallel circuit, they are found as
In Figures 4 and 5, the minimum amplitude calibration is represented by the dotted curves.

sec.title: Fixed-point calibration
sec.p: In Yamada et al. (2010) and Kozlowski et al. (2011), the parameters for the circuit are determined by a fixed-point method similar to that applied for the design of mechanical tuned mass dampers (Den Hartog, 1956). For the series circuit, this leads to
while for the parallel circuit, it gives

It is seen that the minimum frequency response approach in equations (45) and (46) leads to identical frequency calibration, while the damping calibration is slightly different. In Figures 4 and 5, the fixed-point calibration is represented by the dashed–dotted curves.

sec.title: Balanced calibration
sec.p: A balanced calibration of the resonant damping is proposed. It is based on equal modal damping and sufficient separation of the complex poles to avoid constructive interference. For the series circuit, it leads to
while for the parallel circuit, it gives

Note that this calibration is similar to the maximum damping calibration in equations (43) and (44) except for the factor
2
on the damping parameter. It is observed that this pole placement calibration satisfies the relation
